Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 10:39AM Journey wrote: Binney - you have truly been one of my angels thru this whole BC thing.  Thank you for sharing your wisdom.  Congrats and keep up the great work!
Posts.Title: CONGRATS TO OUR DR. BINNEY! OneBadBoob gracejon

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2008 01:25PM Journey wrote: Hi Robin, I had a bilat with expanders just over a month ago. This was my experience so keep in mind yours and others may be different.  I was (and still am) required to wear a firm zip front sports bra 24/7.  I had 3 drains for about 7 days and 1 drain for about 5 more days.  Until those were removed I lived in oversized button up shirts and yoga pants with the drains pinned to the shirt with oversized safety pins.  For me it was difficult hiding the drains - just looked prego.  You will not feel up to much for a while.  I did manage to make a car trip and attend a family wedding about 2 weeks after but I only managed that with pain meds.  Look up my name and you can see my post regarding the trip and what I wore to the wedding.  At about the third week I was able to really get more movement in my arms and sholders which helped me to get back into a lot of my regular clothing. Just last weekend I went to another social event and was able to wear pretty much my normal clothes except I had to hide my sports bra (fashion tape is great).  Hope that helps a little!  Good luck on you surgery!
Posts.Title: Wardrobe tips and social life Texas357 lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2011 03:31AM Journey wrote: Thought i would share. I got mine a couple of years ago from www.fiddleDeeids.com It is a neat system because you can get interchangeable bracelets to swap out your look. I end up wearing a leather cord version because I can keep it on even in the shower. But, I do have a nice girly beaded one I can swap out if I want to dress it up. Mine says - lymphedema alert, no bp, no needles, no iv, both arms. On the front it has the universal medical emblem and then my initials in a beautiful script.
Posts.Title: Medical ID sdinva7 Journey

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2012 01:41PM Journey wrote: My prior posts related to this subject. December 11, 2012 I am getting desperate to find a good seamless shirt with a lower neckline and no logo on top. I've bought everything I can find in hopes it would do the trick. The best I have found is Underarmour but sadly because of the high neckline and or the logo placement I can't hide it under normal street clothes. I also wish the short sleeve versions had just a little longer sleeve so I don't have that gap of upper arm bulge between my compression sleeve and the bottom of the shirt sleeve. On bad days I must wear them inside out because of the seaming irritation so seamless would be a dream. My issue is my upper back near the arm pit so camis and tank are out for me because they cut into that area and make it worse. I have to find a compression top with some sleeve to it. I even took one of my UA shirts to my tailor to see if he could do anything to lower the neckline and he said it can't be done. December 12, 2012 Ladies we have tried to get UA attention before but to my knowledge nothing has come from it. See my topic "New Type of LE garment" then go to page 7. This was back in January 2012. We got all excited that they seemed to be interested but like I said I don't think anything came from it. Although we are a fierce group - we are a small number when you look at the mass population. I just don't think they will be swayed. We may need to start talking to smaller manufacturers, but then we get into a very expensive garment that many of us can't afford or can't afford the number of them that we need in a year. December 18, 2012 I had forgotten that I bought a Ahh Seamless T-shirt by Rhonda Shear (HSN.com) this summer. It's stuck in my closet someplace and I need to dig it back out. The design is kind of what many of us are looking for. I think the compression was decent but gentle and the sleeves are a good longer short sleeve style. But I had issues with it being too thick material (HOT) and the seam work at the shoulders was not done well as it puckers. As I was driving into work it hit me that she might be a good one to reach out too. I jumped on the HSN website today during lunch and sure enough she has a blog there and looks like she actually reads posts and replies from time to time. Soooo I posted a little thing about BC and lymphedema and our needs for a good tshirt design. I'll keep you posted and let you know how you can help.
Posts.Title: Shirt design for Lymphedema Journey McButterfly

Posts.Title: Shirt design for Lymphedema Journey McButterfly

Posts.Content: Journey wrote: Ladies - We are trying to get a manufacturer to design a t-shirt style compression shirt that checks off most of our collective boxes.  If you suffer Lymphedema swelling in your torso you know the frustration of finding a garment that gives some relief, hides well under clothes and doesn't cost an arm and a leg.  I know in my heart that there HAS to be an answer for us.  Many of us have been buying various garments and reporting back on different threads how the garment came close to working or didn't work at all.  I have a very special favor to ask everyone coming to this tread.  Please just post relative to this topic ONLY.  If you have unrelated questions there are lots of threads here in the Lymphedema section and lots of people to help.  Or simply start your own topic with your question.  I don't mean to be ugly but I simply want a single place we can refer any manufacturers who may express interest in designing a T-shirt for us.  I hope you can understand my heart in this. Please tell me what you want in a shirt design.  Did you buy a particular brand and somethings just didn't work that you would need changed?  What would you say to a designer if you could? Thank you ladies! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Shirt design for Lymphedema Journey McButterfly

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2014 05:57AM Journey wrote: Just wanted to pipe in regarding a pocket in the underarm area...for those of us who don't need one there...wouldn't the stitching be an irritant?  My issue is the area between the shoulder blade and where the arm meets the torso, but I find a seam anywhere in the general area to be irritating.  So much so that I wear a t-shirt to bed most nights turned inside out.  Anyway - just another perspective...maybe the pocket version can be a completely different model offered in addition to the "regular" LE shirt?

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2013 11:02AM Journey wrote: Has anyone tried SkinnyTees brand yet?  I found them by accident a couple of weeks ago on line and ordered a cap sleeve T-shirt in suntan (nude) to try out.  It really smelled strong when I got it so I washed it in cold and let it air dry.  Well I wore it yesterday and was comfortable all day!  Now I did wear it inside out since there are seams running under the arms where the sleeve is attached to the body.  There are no side seams! The neckline is a scoop and was perfect under my fashion t-shirt that I was wearing.  My observations are as follows.  SkinnyTees only comes in one size and are supposed to fit size 2 to 22 (or something like that).  I am a size med in street clothes so this fit nicely but was not a strong compression at all.  Hardly any compression, but it did make my t-shirt look pretty darn good as it evened out things.  So I thought it would just be nice for that and nothing else.  Today I am not wearing it and I miss just that gentle compression!  I feel the fluid under my armpit going towards my back, and I really wish I had it on again.  That speaks volumes for me to say that.  I would think that the smaller you are the less this shirt will feel like it does anything, but the larger...maybe could get some very mild compression...I'm guessing?  There are LOTS of styles and even more COLORS!  They are not cheap.  My shirt was $ 42 with shipping.  For those without same issues as me there are tank top and cami styles for less.  Also short sleeve, 3/4 sleeve, long... Hate to encourage anyone to spend yet more money while we wait for our holy grail but if you are desperate like I am you may want to check it out.  www.skinnytees.com Again this is NOT a full compression shirt...just gentle hug kind of thing.  I was surprised this little bit helped me like it did.  I'm happy to try and answer questions about my experience.

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2013 05:14AM Journey wrote: Well Carol it looks like you got the attention we have been needing! I know that no one shirt will make 100% of us happy BUT I know that there are basic design needs we agree on. The right amount of compression (ie UA brand type), unobtrusive neckline sans logo so we can wear under our normal clothes, flat seams to avoid chaffing, and a choice of sleeves - short, long. Isn't that basically it? Oh, and affordable so we can buy several and replace as needed. Nude would be an awesome color choice as well as black and white. Please no pink. Ladies?
Posts.Title: Shirt design for Lymphedema Journey McButterfly

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2014 07:56AM Journey wrote: Following up with suggestions from Spookybob - I tired the Underworks shirt in both Light Cotton and Microfiber in Med. (I am 5'6" &weigh @140ish). The Microfiber was a no go - way too tight in all the wrong places. I kept the Light Cotton but have not worn that for any period of time yet. The Sassybox sleeves are way too tight and would cause a bad problem for me so back it went. I too have tried the Tommy Cooper but in the T-shirt and although I kept it it does not give any real compression so it's just a gym shirt for me. I will share that I have had some success with the SkinnyTees line. Currently I am using their "sports" bra, camis and cap sleeve shirts. They are not cheap (but affordable), and it only comes in one size. For me with my size arms, chest, back, etc it give me a nice gentle compression. If you are much smaller it may not work for you. Anyway, it looks nice and feels great for my needs - unless I am full blown and then I pull out the stronger stuff. JMO. Fingers crossed on the next GO offering!

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2009 08:36PM Journey wrote: Hello Ana - Hopefully you will get some true veterans to answer you later today.  I have had a bilateral with implants (recent) and I was told that I would be able to return to lifting weights as I did before the BC - just have to heal.  As for the arm getting tired I do have that problem with both arms.  Especially annoying when I am out on a shopping trip.  I can no longer grab the hand basket at the grocery store and zip along throwing in all the stuff I need - no way I can carry that now.  Hopefully in time I can build back up to it.  All this to say maybe you just need to start slowly working on your arms with light weights?  Would be worth speaking to one of your doctors I would think.  Take care! (PS. - I have been told that careful exercise helps lessen the LE issues)
Posts.Title: Arm feel tired after short drive karluway Journey

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2009 02:05PM Journey-Girl wrote: Susan & Goldie...  you girls look awesome !   Thanks for pics.  Helps me understand what to expect (growth wise).   Lisa 1964 - It's coming girl..  all of a sudden your going to have a growth spurt. As for me... on the other side.   Haven't lost mine yet.  Day 12 since first chemo.  I'm just hoping hoping hoping to make it through this weekend with hair...  : )
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2009 09:43PM Journey-Girl wrote: Renee Jean and the rest of the sistas: The day I had to shave my head was without a doubt one of the most emotional days of my life.  My hair was long (about 3-4 inches past shoulders) and blonde (fake of course).   I cried for the longest time, and even now can tear up just thinking about that awful day.  Okay now for my "hair" news...   I am still doing chemo, (I do once a week, every Monday) and have only two left (so exciting, I practically pee myself thinking about it)     So two days ago I could swear I felt nubs under my arms.  I looked under there this morning and OMG I actually have hairs.. that I need to shave !!!!!    Just a few under each arm, but honestly, you would think I just won the lottery.  Can't wait to get in that ol' shower and actually use my razor again.  Who would have ever thought we could actually get excited about arm pit hair ???!!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2010 05:26PM Journey-Girl wrote: It's been a while since I've been on the boards.. I finished chemo in November (10 months) ago and rads in February.  I was on Herceptin until end of May.  I always had very straight fine/thin blonde hair.  My hair has grown in straight and lots of it !  I still can't believe how much hair I have..  I used (and still do) every product anyone mentioned (Nioxin, Nioxin scalp booster, Biotin supplements).  The lashes and brows came back (lashes fell out twice).  I think they (the lashes) took too long to grow in.  But they do.  When my lashes were long enough (stubs) I used the individual lashes for a few months until they grew back to normal looking.   That being said, know this.  you are all perfectly beautiful as you are right at this moment.  And when that's sunk in, use eyeliner, hides the no lash look!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2010 05:27PM - edited Sep 20, 2010 05:27PM by Journey-Girl
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2009 01:26AM Journey-Girl wrote: Love this thread !  I am on the other side.. expecting my hair to fall out any day now.  I am 10 days out from my first chemo treatment. Nodapearl - you go girl !  You inspire us all. Bold - Would love to have seen the gold head.. no pics ? Chainey - you are adorable, and you are rocking the hair. Chelev - what did you hear/read about Black Cohesh ?  I used that for hot flashes when I was in the throes of menopause and it worked awesome.  I know I can't take any herbs while undergoing chemo, but so many write that the hot flashes just keep on coming, even when chemo stops.  Figured I would just start popping the BC pills again.    Also, your sister... I don't even know what to say.  I just feel so bad that for you on that one.  Ball is definetely in her court though, you've reached out enough.     I'll keep reading this thread - know what to expect when I come out the other end of chemo hell.

Posts.Content: May 27, 2009 09:37PM Journey-Girl wrote: I just started chemo... one week ago.  W-a-i-t-i-n-g for the first hair to come out.. and I'm so-o-o sad about it.  I love my hair.  Freaking out about the eyelashes/eyebrows.  Like losing our hair isn't enough?!!  I'm on a journey I don't want to take - so glad to have all these threads to help me get through.

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2008 09:19AM Journey wrote: Did anyone see the brief piece on NBC's morning program today with Dr. Susan Love?  I know I am new to all this but I have her book.  Anyway, she is now advocating finding the CAUSE of BC and has launched a program to get over one million women to join to help with the research.  They are looking for the average woman not yet diagnosed with BC.  Here is a clip from the web site - http://www.armyofwomen.org/ "Most basic research in breast cancer has been done in the laboratory and on animals, or with samples collected and stored from women with breast cancer. Researchers use animals and samples from a "tissue bank" because they don't have ready access to healthy women. But what we learn from animals doesn't always translate into how cancer develops in women, and tissue only from women with cancer may not help solve the puzzle of what caused the cancer. The Army of Women will allow researchers to conduct a wider array of studies and to solve the puzzle as to how breast cancer starts and how to stop it in women!" I'm glad to see something like this starting to become a reality.  Let's find a cause and then maybe we can get a cure.
Posts.Title: Christina Applegate my new hero KiminJax Daffodil

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2008 10:21AM Journey wrote: BMac - I could not agree with you more - I hated the statement that Cancer is a blessing...WHAT???  And you are right - they focused on the brave face and not the real stuff. Liz - Can you do anything to promote the Armyofwomen thing?  I know I am about to hit all my family and friends with it! Hey Felicia - hey!  You know sometimes the most complicated things are solved when you can stand back and really observe it.  Maybe her new approach will be the key to the answer.
Posts.Title: Christina Applegate my new hero KiminJax Daffodil

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2008 09:37AM Journey wrote: I was also in just one night but could have stayed for two.  My nurse was an angel and "pushed" me to get out of bed and start shuffling down the hall.  The more I walked the faster my temp went back to normal and then I was able to keep liquids down.  Until that point I just wanted to be left alone in bed.  Anyway, listen to your body and your medical team.  I do think if you can getting out of bed is the first step towards feeling more human again.

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2009 09:38AM Journey wrote: Hi Kira - thanks for the information.  Think we posted above about the same time.  I may look into the videos / book you mentioned.  Yep - it's not a cheap problem to have. As a foot note - My LE started after my tissue expander on one side had to be replaced.  That was the 3rd surgery on that side of my chest in as many months at that point.  Anyway, in subsequent visits to my PS when I would wear my LE compression bra or have a sleeve on he would smile and point to it and say "whats this?" in a tone of voice like hey -you don't really have this problem do you?  I could never afford to spend the 2 minutes he would give me for the appointment by explaining that yes - I really DO have this damn problem.

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2009 10:07AM Journey wrote: Pat - I also want to hear more about the swell spot glove as I have swelling in my hand as well.  I was fitted for a sleeve and gauntlet but ended up tearing the gauntlet at the seams because it was too small across my hand. (Would actually draw my thumb up under towards my palm) So I asked her about a medium which she felt would be fine since I have very little swelling.  Well the med. fits SO much better but now I am getting ridges and lumps on the top of my hand which I assume is fluid build up.  I need to go back and talk to her about this but was just wondering about what you found if that may take care of my problem too.  Thanks! Kira - it does all suck some days!  On these days I just want my mommy to be here to take care of things and me.  Unfortunately she lost her battle 26 years ago.  I was just a teen but I wish I had been there more for her now that I have some idea the path she walked.

Posts.Content: Journey wrote: I have stage 1 lymphedema in my upper right arm which when flares up can end up in my upper back and arm pit area.  Before bilat I was into martial arts and just weeks away from taking my black belt test.  I need to get real about this condition and my new restrictions.  Do I return to training?  Will I ever be able to punch  on a padded target with any force or would that be a real danger? And a question about sleeves / gauntlet.  I sit all day at a desk on a computer.  Should I wear it everyday or just reserve for exercise?  (I've discovered I have to wear it if I go out shopping or I really pay the price later!)  My PT said just wear it for physical stuff but I swear my arm is getting heavier as time goes on so just wondering if it would help or hurt? Thank you ladies! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Help me come to terms Journey Marple

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2009 09:24AM Journey wrote: sisterinspirit -(love the name!) - I checked my PT's card and it has "MSOT/L-CLT" then "Board Certified Lymphedema Therapist" under that.  She seems pretty knowledgeable but think she has only been doing LE for about 3 years. She works in my hospital's rehab center.  Hopefully I am in good hands!  As for a compressing bra - I ended up with a Bellisse Compression bra. It's gosh awful looking and long but really helped me keep the LE out of my back which is were it really started for me after my 3rd surgery.  I got two of them from my PT and my insurance paid for both so you may start there. Baywatcher - okay if we are going to have a support group I vote we meet at your place!  Even though I live in GA I have yet to make it to Key West.  Gonna do that one of these days! Hi Estepp - I hope you are not asking because you think you may have it? For me the swelling was not visible except to a trained eye.  A LE PT will be able to take measurements (if in the arms, hands), and can tell better.  Mine started as a feeling of fullness in my back near my armpit that didn't go away after surgery swelling subsided.  Then I became aware of a real tenderness and the feeling of pin pricks all day long in the underneath fleshy part of my upper arm.  On a bad day it hurts when someone just pats me on the shoulder or arm (we tend to do that a lot here in the South!)
Posts.Title: Help me come to terms Journey Marple

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2009 02:28PM Journey wrote: Hi Binney - I have been a few times to a PT who works out of the local hospital.  My PT is not on the list but someone else in her group is. She has taught me and my husband how to do the massage, but said I don't need to wrap at night. My insurance will only allow 15 visits a year so I am being kind of stingy in when I go.  Last calendar year I did go 2x a week for 2 weeks but then I had the exchange surgery.  Went 2 x last month.  If anything I think I am worse now. To begin with I had the pins and needles pain in the arm and fullness feeling in my back.  Now my arm feels full and heavy and occasionally I feel actual twinges of pain. I guess I need to start doing self massage everyday instead of waiting for DH to do it 3 times or so a week.  So is it possible to get better? I know I am at danger in both arms and do take care.  Only have sleeve and gauntlet for right.  Have the bras that I don't wear except sometimes at night. I have not been taught how to wrap so guess I need to look into that. I think until now I have really been in a form of denial over the LE.  I don't want this and don't want to take the time to deal with it.  How should I go about my day with LE?  Wake up and clear the nodes in the shower, pull on sleeve / glove, take deap breaths during the day, get some form of excercise, remove sleeve 1 hour afterwards, do massage, then wrap before bed?  Is that basically what I should be doing?
Posts.Title: Help me come to terms Journey Marple

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2009 08:19AM Journey wrote: Binney - This was so well put I want to frame it.  Thanks again! "Lymphedema starts out being completely overwhelming, taking over every thought, ruining every plan -- and then gradually you manage to take change of it and sort it all out, and it starts to come together into something you can actually control. We learn everything we need to know, and then we decide on the compromises we're willing to make."
Posts.Title: Help me come to terms Journey Marple

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2009 01:48PM Journey wrote: Hi Binney & Ladies - Been busy past couple of days so have not posted.  I have an appt with my LE PT this week and hope to discuss more with her. I asked her over the phone to go ahead and order another sleeve for me.  (I can get 2 a year and promptly lost one of them!  Have since learned better how to keep up with it if I do remove it during the day.)  So far I have had two workout sessions with free weights and have used 8lb dumb bells to do curls with NO issues to my arm(s).  Of course I wear a sleeve and gauntlet and keep both on for a couple of hours after wards.  I still have not returned to karate and that is part of what I want to discuss in depth with my PT this week.  My LE is mild so I am hoping that maybe I can make enough modifications to return to my workout and be okay.  Guess if I do something and I end up swelling up the worst that can happen is it takes time to get the swelling back under control?  Or will I have done any permanent damage at that point?  In other words how bad would it be to try karate again in your opinion (s)?
Posts.Title: Help me come to terms Journey Marple

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2008 03:43PM Journey wrote: Beesi - thank you so much for your information. I am concerned about too many decisions being made while I am on the table so I will have to have a clear understanding of how he would proceed. On the other hand I would prefer he get as much sample as they feel they need so I won't have to go back again for him to get more. Carolynn233 - I think I really understand your process.  Having lost my mother to this and watching by daddy and brother lose their lives too young to cancers I will consider a complete mastectomy if things point in that direction.  Part of me just wants to be done with the possibility - and I know this process has just begun.  Keep us posted please. I'll be sure to post after my meeting on 8/4. Sure I'll have even more to think about then.  In the meantime I am going to continue to prepare for my black belt test in September and have a wonderful anniversary at the beach with my husband next week.  Gotta stay strong and keep positive! Hugs to you all

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2008 12:53PM Journey wrote: Thanks to all.  I have made it very clear to my surgeon and Plastic surgeon and both of their office staff that my mother was dx of BC had radical mast.and we still lost her to mets 6 years later.  I just don't see how they can deny the claim.  I am also having Alloderm and know I may have to fight that but my PS said my skin is too thin to accept an implant otherwise.  (I won't let him take any muscle.)  I have a small business so I am the plan admin.  Got on the line with my insurance rep a few days ago and she is doing all she can I believe to get UH to bone up.  Anyway, I have signed up for the whole shooting match and going with it on 9/3.  And I'll worry about fighting it later. Oh, just got the prebill on my little surgical biopsy and so far the cost from that is over $18,000.  Unfriggin believable!  Of course insurance will argue that down and it will be adjusted - I'll pay my chunk of change on the deductible of my policy then 20%....  so much for that race horse I was saving up for!  (Kidding  )

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2012 09:27PM Journey wrote: Done!  My request below: "I think your company has already received some requests for a seamless shirt design, and I wanted to follow up on that.  As a result of breast cancer surgery, statistically many, many of us end up with a condition called Lymphedema which can cause uncomfortable swelling in our arms, chest, back (we call trunctal).  To prevent additional swelling, and to aid in general comfort we are advised to wear compression camis or shirts.  Since our swelling is as individual as each of us we can not all find the same garment to do the trick - except for UnderArmour shirts.  BUT, the problem we have is that the seams are irritating to our LE.  So we wear the shirts inside out.  Another issue is that because we need to wear these with our everyday clothes the neckline and logos placement can be very problematic.  Please consider a shirt design to fit our unique needs.  No manufacturer has addressed this that is affordable to the average woman.  Thank you for your kind consideration."
Posts.Title: New type of LE Garment Journey purple32

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2008 07:23AM Journey wrote: Hi Fran - I think what you are feeling is very normal!  At 2 weeks I was still a mess.  Heck even at 2 months I was still dragging.  This whole experience takes a toll on your body and your mind so give yourself a break and understand that it will get better.  I was very physically active right up to my bilat but it was not until around week 6 that I began to feel that I wanted to do anything.  Started back to work part time towards the end of week 3 but by the end of week 4 I was back to my full time desk job.  Jelly is correct that you need to eat well as your body does need the right nutrients to heal.  For pain you might want to inquire about Loratab.  It is a milder pain killler that may allow you to function without being so wiped out like the stronger pain killers will do. Hang in there!

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2011 09:10AM Journey wrote: I should ask for a special discount, right? Okay, I have the armcare and the silverwave and have worn both a few times.  For a sleeve I LOVE the armcare.  I am one of those folks who hates tight clothing (making a bee line to my closet when I get home to get in my comfy house clothes!), so wearing sleeves has been very hard for me.  That said, the armcare version has been much easier to tolerate than my regular sleeve.  No longer am I pulling and tugging on the arm band to pull it up all day.  I plan on saving up and buying another one soon.  Now, the silverwave I'm still on the fence on.  I don't know but it just seems hot and I don't really care for the thickness around the wrists.  Just me!  I'll keep wearing as it does make me feel better but I just don't see myself wearing into the warmer months.  Maybe I'll change my mind later. Hope the armcare will come out in more colors!

Think I will contact this company and ask if they will make a combo sleeve like this that covers the shoulder blade area too. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2009 11:31PM Journey-Girl wrote: Today is my day 14..   Everyday I give my hair a little tug and am so happy that it is firmly in place.  Took a shower last night and when I got out gave a gentle tug.  And sure enough my hair was still firmly in place.  Had not lost even one little 'ol strand.   This morning woke up (again, day number 14) gave a gentle little tug and ... HOLY CRAP!  it just tugged right out of my scalp.  I just sat there stunned, looking at my hair in my hand.   And this is how my day has gone.  The hair is just gently coming out.     : (
Posts.Title: Does everyone loose their hair during TC chemo myagirl Sharon648

Posts.Content: Journey wrote: Hello - new to the board - and thankful I found it!  Brief backgd - 48 years old. Mother first diag.at 55 and lost her at 63 to BC. Lost Dad and a brother to diff. cancers as well.  Anyway been good about my mamos and just went for my yearly + a 6 mo followup ultrasd on left when low and behold left now looks stable but there are two areas in right.  Was told by the radiologist that I need a biopsy.  So have a meeting scheduled in 3 wks to meet with surgeon.  So here are some questions please.  The areas are as I understand under nipple towards inside of chest (don't know if that is 11:00 or 1:00? And then the other is "way in the back" on the upper and outer most part of the breast.  I am very active - lift weights and do martial arts.  I am told by my doctor that this surgeon will keep me on the table and send biopsy to lab and keep cutting until he has all clear.  How cut up will I end up being?  I always had in my head that a biopsy is just a simple extraction of a few cells via some small needle.  I don't trust doctors to really tell the whole truth so I am looking for real people with life experience to help me here. Need to be prepared on what to ask. Any thoughts?  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Biopsy question... Journey Journey

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 08:45AM Journey wrote: Thanks Ann - I sure hope that will be the case for me as well.  It's just unbelievable the stress it can put a family through.  You have to pick your battles and for now it is getting thru the surgery and healing.  We can always get a loan I guess!  BTW - I am assuming from your nickname that you are in NYC?  My hubby and I have always said if we "win the lottery" we would rent a place in NYC for 6 months and just drink in the life there.  Best food, music, atmosphere in the world. Gotta love it!
Posts.Title: Insurance and the healthy breast Journey BethNY

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 09:12AM Journey wrote: They will not pay for the expanders and alloderm that will be used or the surgeons fee for removal of the healthy breast tissue.  Also will not pay for the fills and expander exchange which will be needed later.  They would cover an immediate implant to make the healthy breast "match" the rebuilt one if I just did the single mast.  That's the rub.
Posts.Title: Insurance and the healthy breast Journey BethNY

Posts.Content: Journey wrote: Have IDC in right breast and have elected to have my left (healthy) breast removed at same time.  Lost my mother to BC and her mother had ovarian (but died of old age).  So now my practical husband wants to find out just how large of a loan we are going to have to take out.  All kidding aside - it is a decision we are solid with.  I have United Healthcare PPO and we are being told that they can't tell us what they will cover until the actual claim is made. I know that if any bc is found in the path report on the left then there will be no question about coverage.  Oh, I will also have expanders at the same time.  Anybody been down this path before and can share some information I would appreciate it very much! Thank you. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Insurance and the healthy breast Journey BethNY

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2008 09:39AM Journey wrote: Abinneb - Thanks - you are right about doctors.  I didn't mean to imply that they lie but I know from family exp. they sure don't tell it all (like I would like).  But you are correct in that they may not have the first hand knowledge to share. Leaf - I am sorry I don't know the technical name (all my pamphlets are in my car right now) but what the radiologist said is the type when they insert the wire for the surgeon to follow.  However my doc said that the surgeon may do a different type and I will know more when I meet with him on 8/4. My breasts are a wannabe B and I don't carry a lot of weight on my upper torso.  Think what has me a little freaked is that area towards the back.  They had a heck of a time trying to get it positioned right in the compression plates to get a good look at it.  So it is near muscle I fear. What I have are two areas of microcalcifications. Not sure from the report how clustered they are. Thanks for the input!

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2008 05:46AM Journey wrote: Hi BethBY - my date is 9/3.  I may do the genetic testing but will wait until the law fully covers it in June 09 (I believe that's the date).  I do have a son by birth but my daughter is my step d. so I only have to worry about him if my genes prove to be a problem.  Well quite frankly I know my genes are a problem because I have lost both parents and a brother to different cancers and now my other brother has been diagnosed this month with yet another cancer.  That just leaves one sister who has yet to be stricken by the big "C".  I am sure my family has some genetic mutation but it won't just be the BC gene at work. Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 08:19AM Journey wrote: I have heard back from my insurance rep who got an answer from United Healthcare that they will deny the coverage on the healthy breast...unless I can provide more information which they will review.  (Well, let's start with I lost my mother to BC and mets.) Screw that for now.  I am having the surgery on 9/3 with expanders and will allow my surgeons to make the case for me while I heal.  If that doesn't work then I'll have to see what I can plead on my own.  mradf I agree with you that this should be addressed in a larger forum just as the right to a balanced reconstruction was.  I don't think if women are given the right to remove their healthy breast(s) that there will be a run on the insurance companies by women en mass to have their healthy breasts removed, but it would absolutely help those who have bc in one breast make the decision based on what they as an individual want and not what their family can or can not afford.  Just incredible.

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2010 09:06AM Journey wrote: Kira - where can I find it?
Posts.Title: A surgeon who gets it Journey jacee

Posts.Content: Journey wrote: I wanted to share this.  Dr. Marga Massey did my SGap recon last week in New Orleans.  She operates in Charleston, Utah, and Chicago I believe as well.  Anyway, this woman is incredible as for her care and concern for our LE.  I can't help but think that if she had been my surgeon 2 years ago I would not now be dealing with LE in my arm and trunk.  I want you to know that she has ALL of her patients see a wonderful LE therapist at pre-op who measures and does a great job with education.  Then the morning of surgery I am shocked to see Dr. Massey arrive with this huge cart of supplies and she goes to work personally to wrap both of my arms and support with foam etc before I am put under.  She spent at least 30 - 45 minutes talking to me, wrapping me, adjusting if needed, rubbing a fantastic lotion on my skin.  When she was finished with my affected arm I felt immediate relief.  Then hours after post-op she returned to my bedside and removed the bandages and left them with me to bring for my follow up surgery in March.  I am now 12 days post op and have just now started to feel a little of my normal swelling develop.  Until this morning I have had no LE issues since the operation.  She is an incredible surgeon who is also on a mission to educate patients AND surgeons to PREVENT Lymphedema brought on by surgery. Imagine that.  Major Kudos to Dr. Massey and any surgeons who are brave enough to follow her campaign! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: A surgeon who gets it Journey jacee
